channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Fighting Rages as Ukraine Battles to Hold the East
item.description: President Biden says the U.S. will send another $1 billion in equipment and arms. Several NATO allies are also pledging more military help, including ammunition, long-range artillery rocket systems and helicopters.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: The TikTok Star and Political Chameleon Vying for Colombia’s Presidency
item.description: Rodolfo Hernández bills himself as a paragon of democracy and a successful businessman who cares for the poor. A trip to Bucaramanga, the mountain-fringed city where he built his empire, reveals a different picture.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:description: The Colombian presidential candidate Rodolfo Hernández, with his wife, Socorro Oliveros, holding the microphone, during a campaign event in Barranquilla, Colombia.

item.title: With Northern Ireland and Migrants, Johnson Swings Cudgel of Survival Politics
item.description: Critics say the British leader’s hardened stances on Northern Ireland and immigration are cynical pandering to the pro-Brexit Tories he needs to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at a news conference in Blackpool earlier this month.

item.title: Attack on Women in China Stirs Outrage, and Competing Narratives
item.description: Graphic footage of an attack in a restaurant fueled online debate that showed both the growing awareness of women’s rights and how divisive feminism still remains.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video showing two women lying on the ground after being assaulted by a group of men outside a restaurant in the northeastern city of Tangshan, China, in June.

item.title: U.K. Vows to Press Ahead With Deportations to Rwanda
item.description: The government said it would stick with a plan to send asylum seekers to the African country, despite the first flight’s grounding after a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Stephen Castle
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The plane that was to take asylum seekers to Rwanda at an air base in Wiltshire, southern England, on Tuesday. Critics have branded Britain’s policy inhumane and impractical.

item.title: North of Kyiv, the Russians Retreated. But the War Never Left.
item.description: In the Ukrainian villages near the Russian border, shells still explode and checkpoints and trenches dot the landscape. And wary civilians live in fear the enemy will return.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena and Mykola Kalivoshko, both 65, who are from the village of Senkivka, Ukraine, cry as they recount how they fled to nearby Moshchenka because of Russian shelling.

item.title: Ryanair Drops South African Passport Test After Protests
item.description: The Irish budget airline had imposed a test in Afrikaans, a language with a racist legacy and that many South Africans don’t speak, to weed out fake documents.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Eligon
item.media:description: A Ryanair aircraft landing at Gatwick Airport in Crawley, Britain, in 2021.

item.title: Monkeypox Outbreak Poses ‘Real Risk’ to Public Health, W.H.O. Official Says
item.description: Dr. Hans Kluge, the organization’s director for Europe, said that the longer the virus circulated, the wider its reach would be.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:description: A sample to be tested for monkeypox at a lab in La Paz University Hospital, Madrid, this month. Europe has emerged as the epicenter of the outbreak.

item.title: Israel Convicts Palestinian Aid Worker on Charges of Funding Hamas
item.description: Mohammad El Halabi was charged with funneling millions from a Christian charity to the militant group. The charity, World Vision, said there was no evidence to support that and the trial lacked transparency.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Right-wing Israeli protesters, right, arguing with supporters, left, of Mohammad El Halabi, the Gaza director of World Vision, at a district court in the southern Israeli city of Beersheva on Wednesday.

item.title: Athens Court Opens Appeals Hearing for Imprisoned Golden Dawn Members
item.description: Dozens of members of the extreme-right party, which was deemed a criminal organization by the Greek judiciary, were convicted in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Members of the far-right Golden Dawn party surrounded by police during appeals proceedings in Athens on Wednesday.

item.title: In South Asia, Climate Change Worries Take On Fresh Urgency
item.description: Hundreds of millions of humanity’s most vulnerable live in South Asia, where rising temperatures make it more difficult to address poverty, food insecurity and health challenges.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Hifjur Rehman, 40, a third-generation farmer, collapsed in a paddy field destroyed by floods in the Indian state of Assam. Mr. Rehman had been worried about how to repay a loan to the bank.

item.title: For Its Next Zero Covid Chapter, China Turns to Mass Testing
item.description: Residents in many cities must show negative P.C.R. tests to go shopping or use public services. The policy may hamper efforts to revive the economy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Workers waiting to show their health codes and proof of a negative Covid-19 test outside a Beijing office building in May.

item.title: The Grenfell Fire, 5 Years Later: What Happened, and What Has Changed
item.description: The fire quickly engulfed the apartment building, fueled by cladding now banned. An investigation is continuing. But the families of the 72 who died find accountability slow in coming.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grenfell Tower has been clad in plastic sheeting since the fire in 2017.

item.title: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a majority that will pass his bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters displayed on Tuesday in Allex, a village in southeastern France.

item.title: Heading to Ukraine, the Leaders of France and Germany Face a Tense Reception
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France have had strained relations with Ukraine’s leaders since Russia invaded, struggling to balance support for Kyiv with the rising economic costs of the war.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian artillery gunners last month reloading while engaged in an exchange with Russian forces four miles away near the village of Vuhledar, in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Urban Artillery Battle in Ukraine Sends Civilians Running in the East
item.description: Heavy volleys between Russian forces taking control of Sievierodonetsk and Ukrainian forces in a neighboring city are leaving wreckage and growing desperation for the residents stuck there.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Lysychansk, across a river from the embattled city of Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: $1 Billion to Ukraine
item.description: Plus the Fed raised interest rates and a video of an assault in China went viral.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents line up for humanitarian assistance provided by a German NGO in the town of Irpin, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Pledge Additional Arms for Ukraine, but Kyiv Wants More
item.description: Some NATO countries are wary of sending heavy weapons, hoping for a negotiated truce, but the alliance insists publicly that it is committed to helping Ukraine defeat Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III, left, and Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, speaking at a NATO ministers’ meeting on Wednesday in Brussels.

item.title: Man Confesses to Killing Journalist and Indigenous Activist, the Police Say
item.description: Dom Phillips, a freelance reporter for The Guardian, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples, have been missing in the Amazon since June 5.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol, Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Police escorted a suspect in the disappearances of a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples onto a boat on Wednesday morning in Atalaia do Norte, Brazil.

item.title: Billions of Dollars Laundered Annually in British Columbia
item.description: Government officials in the province of British Columbia were aware that suspicious money was entering their revenue stream, but took no steps to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Vjosa Isai and Tracy Sherlock
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A worker cleaning windows at a hotel and casino in Vancouver, British Columbia. A new government report says that billions of dollars a year have been laundered in British Columbia by criminals, using tactics such as gambling in casinos.

item.title: What’s to Come in Russia’s Fight for Sievierodonetsk in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The United Nations says that hundreds of civilians are trapped with besieged Ukrainian forces at a chemical plant and “are suffering and experiencing constant shelling and bombardment.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Civilians in April outside of the Azot chemical plant’s bomb shelter in Sievierodonetsk, where they had been hiding from shelling since the beginning of the war.

item.title: From the Wreckage of Caribbean Migration, a New Kind of Beauty
item.description: Four artists created stories of resilience from the traumatic histories of ancestors, on view at the Ford Foundation Gallery.
item.dc:creator: Aruna D’Souza
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andil Gosine, curator of the exhibition “Everything Slackens in a Wreck” at the Ford Foundation, which showcases the work of artists of Asian-Caribbean origin.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Eases Some Covid Precautions Before the Hajj
item.description: Even as coronavirus cases rise steadily, the kingdom has announced the lifting of most Covid precautions as it prepares to receive roughly a million Muslim pilgrims.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims arrive at Saudi Arabia’s King Abdulaziz International Airport in Jeddah on June 5.

item.title: Ukraine has only a fraction of the weapons it needs from the West, a Kyiv official says.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers performing maintenance on an American-made Howitzer last month in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Urges Allies to Increase Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: After announcing a major new wave of long-range weaponry for Ukraine, Western leaders will turn their sights toward other potential threats to NATO from Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Michael D. Shear and Dan Bilefsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Can a Law Protecting Endangered Animals Stop New Oil Drilling?
item.description: Environmentalists say the government failed to study the threats to endangered species from climate change before issuing oil and gas drilling permits.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A critically endangered Hawaiian monk seal rested on an Oahu beach in Hawaii.

item.title: In Call With Putin, China’s Xi Offers Closer Cooperation with Russia
item.description: The Chinese government has tried to keep good ties with Moscow while maintaining that it wants to be an impartial broker for peace in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Xi Jinping of China at a meeting in Beijing in February before the war in Ukraine began.

item.title: U.A.E. Bans ‘Lightyear,’ Disney Film with Same-Sex Kiss
item.description: The United Arab Emirates banned the animated film, an offshoot of the “Toy Story” movies, from its cinemas. Censors in Indonesia and Malaysia are also considering restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Alisha Hawthorne, voiced by Uzo Aduba, in a scene from “Lightyear.” The character kisses her wife in one scene, which has prompted restrictions on the film in some countries.

item.title: Macron Says He Wants a Ukraine Victory, But Underlines Talks as Necessary
item.description: During a visit to Romania, the French president appeared intent on addressing criticism that he was placing pressure on Kyiv to enter into peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Klaus Iohannis of Romania reviewed NATO troops near Constanta, Romania, on Wednesday.

item.title: Constructive Communication Between the U.S. and China Gets Harder
item.description: Later this month, the United States and China may face another threat in their already fraught relations.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Gandel
item.media:credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheng Li of the Brookings Institution attends a task force meeting on China during the 2022 New York Times DealBook conference in Washington. At left is Robert Daly, the director of the Kissinger Institute on China.

item.title: Why Doctors Are Divided Over Gender-Affirming Care for Children
item.description: Doctors who provide gender-affirming care are split on how to evaluate teens.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:credit: Anne Vetter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tori, 13, told her parents in seventh grade that she didn’t want a boy’s body.

item.title: How the Institute for the Study of War tries to provide a clearer picture of the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Yana Dlugy
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Space sensors can detect heat from artillery strikes.

item.title: NATO’s leader pledges more military aid as Ukraine says weapons are slow to arrive.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: While some American-made howitzers and other NATO-provided heavy weapons have arrived to the country, Ukrainian officials have pressed for speedier delivery of heavy weapons, as well as more sophisticated weaponry.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine falters in the east.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Prymachenko was buried at Lukyanivsky Military Cemetery. Mr. Prymachenko was killed on June 5th, near Bakhmut in the Donetsk region of Ukraine.

item.title: Search for Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira Becomes a Homicide Investigation
item.description: The police arrested a second suspect after Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Araújo Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous people, went missing.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol, Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Indigenous people helping Navy personnel in the search for the Indigenous expert Bruno Pereira and the freelance British journalist Dom Phillips on Tuesday in Atalaia do Norte, Amazonas State, Brazil.

item.title: Kyiv City Ballet plans its first U.S. tour in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:description: Members of Kyiv City Ballet with artists from the Opera National du Rhin in an open class in Mulhouse, France.

item.title: Russian Coal Mine Responsible for Huge Methane Leaks
item.description: In January, a satellite detected 13 plumes of methane, a potent planet-warming gas, coming from the largest coal mine in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The Raspadskya coal mine in Mezhdurechensk, Russia, in February 2021. In 2010, a methane explosion there killed 66 workers.

item.title: In villages north of Kyiv, residents still feel the war’s presence.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Toronto Mass Killer Sentenced Under Shadow of Supreme Court Ruling
item.description: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled recently that even the worst offenders can seek parole after 25 years, declaring life sentences without parole to be unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Survivors of the van attack and their families gathered outside the Toronto Courthouse as the crown attorney Joe Callaghan read a statement following the verdict in the trial of accused van attacker Alek Minassian last year.

item.title: Canadians traveling within the country’s borders will no longer need to show proof of vaccination.
item.description: The mandate, which was implemented last fall, will end on June 20 for people traveling domestically, Canadian officials said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Carly Olson
item.media:description: Starting on June 20, Canadians traveling domestically will no longer need to show proof of vaccination.

item.title: A Link to Besieged Ukrainians Is Cut, as Allies Question Strategy
item.description: The last bridge to the city of Sievierodonetsk fell as street battles raged, and some Western officials questioned Ukraine’s ability to keep resisting the Russian onslaught.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian regional police force patrolled near the Siversky Donets River, which divides the cities of Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk, last week.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Sievierodonetsk, Isolated
item.description: The key Ukrainian city lost its last bridge as fighting intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: How Travelers to Europe Can Deal With the Summer’s Chaos
item.description: Hours in security lines. Canceled flights. Lost baggage. Here’s a look at how you could be affected by travel disruptions this summer and tips on how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: At Amsterdam’s Schiphol airport, passengers waited up to six hours in security lines earlier this month.

item.title: In an eastern city, desperate fighting as the last bridge goes down.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers walked past damaged buildings in Lysychansk, across the Siversky Donets River from the besieged city of Sievierodonetsk, on Monday.

item.title: The U.S. says it won’t pressure Ukraine to negotiate an end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed American-made artillery equipment in a field outside the city of Lysychansk, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Moscow Court Orders Brittney Griner Held in Jail for Another 18 Days
item.description: The American basketball star was arrested in February in a Russian airport amid tensions over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and attempts to win her release have repeatedly failed.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, one of the W.N.B.A.’s highest profile stars, has been under Russian detention since February of this year. On Tuesday, Ms. Griner had her detention extended by a Moscow court until July.

item.title: Here’s a look at what’s next after F.D.A. advisers voted to recommend Moderna’s vaccine for children 6 to 17.
item.description: The panel’s recommendation was a key step in the process as federal regulators weigh authorizing the vaccine for those children, but it is not the final say.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid and Johnny Diaz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Bess Adler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vial of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine at Altru Chemists pharmacy in Brooklyn last year.

item.title: Grenfell Tower Fire Families Gather and Ask for Justice
item.description: Survivors, friends and families gathered in London to honor lost loved ones, but a hunger for accountability permeated the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Tuesday was the fifth anniversary of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people in London. A government inquiry continues, and there have been no charges thus far.

item.title: How Cats Make the Most of Their Catnip High
item.description: A new study finds that the feline reaction to catnip and silver vine helps to stave off mosquitoes and other bloodsucking insects.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: The blossoming catnip plant was found to release 2,000 percent more bug-repelling iridoids when damaged by cats.

item.title: Cambodia Sentences Theary Seng and Other Hun Sen Critics to Prison
item.description: Theary Seng, a Cambodian American lawyer, and dozens of other critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen were convicted of conspiracy to commit treason.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Theary Seng, dressed as Lady Liberty, was taken away by the police after her conviction in Cambodia. She has worn a series of extravagant costumes as a form of nonverbal protest.

item.title: Canada and Denmark Settle the Ownership of an Arctic Island After 49 Years
item.description: The two countries agreed to divide an island that sits between Canada and Greenland and defined the area’s international border.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Denmark and Canada signed an agreement Tuesday splitting up the land rights to Hans Island, a small piece of land in the Arctic that sits on the sea border between the two nations.

item.title: Haze Fan of Bloomberg News Released From Chinese Detention
item.description: Haze Fan was taken into custody in 2020 and has not been heard from since. Chinese officials announced last month that she had been freed in January, but many questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Journalists crowd a press conference for China’s legislature in 2019. News organisations have been facing an increasingly hostile reporting environment in China.

item.title: Biden Trip to Saudi Arabia Is Set, but Energy Help Is Not
item.description: The White House formally announced that President Biden would visit the oil-rich kingdom in mid-July despite having denounced it as a “pariah” state after the assassination of a dissident.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden will make his first trip to the Middle East as president from July 13 to July 16, stopping first in Israel and the West Bank before heading to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Flight of Asylum Seekers From Britain to Rwanda Is Halted
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s plan to fly asylum seekers to Rwanda to address arrivals across the English Channel has been criticized as unworkable and unethical.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Cora Engelbrecht and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arrivals from the English Channel brought ashore in Dover, England, last year. Such crossings have been a growing political problem for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

item.title: Zimbabwe Court Convicts Reporter for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, is unlikely to spend time in prison, but analysts said the case was part of a wider assault on press freedoms in the country.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo, a respected Zimbabwean journalist who has worked for The New York Times and other international news organizations, said on Tuesday after his conviction, “I’m innocent.”

item.title: Inflation and Price Gouging
item.description: We look at whether “greedflation” is causing higher prices.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Grocery shopping in Manhattan.

item.title: The loss of a final bridge to Sievierodonetsk may hurt Ukraine’s ability to hold its ground.
item.description: The last bridge linking the eastern city with Ukrainian-controlled territory to the west has been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Sievierodonetsk on Sunday during intense fighting between Ukrainian and Russian forces.
